reviewText:
Beautiful intro scene, flying and swooping around the galaxy, so pretty... and then the game starts.

If you like your platformer difficulty based solely on controllability then this is the game for you!
2 button controls - thrust and fire. For the most part you are automatically moving forward, there is no back or stop unless you count rocks and scenery. Unbreakable rocks scattered along the ground must be scaled with the thrust, but thrust has to be used very gently else you fly off the top of the screen and that kills. Timing is everything or you bang into enemies, gas clouds and many other things that will kill you, some being quite hard to see against the background.
Some levels have you in a turret position and all you have to do is shoot, these levels are too easy and ultimately dull.

There is a choice of weapons pre stage start and none of them blew me away, excuse the pun. The menu system where you choose your stage/level and especially the replay/after death (which you will see a lot of) are poorly designed and irritating. The graphics and sound are nothing special. The whole thing felt more like a mobile app game.

After finishing a few levels and getting used to the controls, I made myself a drink and completely forgot I was playing it. I feel no draw to complete it.

reviewText:
'm left wondering why this game was even made and who decided that offering it to the public would be a good idea.

It feels like an unfinished student's project, and I don't even want to know how the imprecise controls work on a tiny mobile device's screen, especially when you really have to get lucky at times, in order to get through some of the tiny, passable gaps, barely squeezing your ship between two environmental hazards.

I was attracted by the colorful visuals, even if they feel like a mashup of several different designs that don't really go together, expecting a tight shooter, and was left disappointed by what seems to be an incomplete prototype that doesn't yet have all the mechanics implemented.

You can't steer the robot, if you touch a cloud you die, stuff suddenly collapses and kills you, it's basically a quick time event cinematic with lousy flow and no testing, that makes even Flappy Bird look like a game with some though put into it.
